text: <h2>Welcome to the Bio4Community CLUE Teacher Guide!<h2>

Each small group in your classroom will read one of the three Bio4Community Stress Stories, about Rakesh, Estrella, or Felix. The stories are accessed through the Concord Portal at https://learn.concord.org.
To get started, register as a teacher and log into the Concord Portal Then, follow these steps:

1. Create a class for each small group in the Concord portal.
  2. Create a unique access code for each group of students, called the "class word"
  3. Give each group their class word and have them register for student accounts.
  4. Contact Frieda (freichsman@concord.org) who will assign the chapters for the stories to each group for you.
  5. You will then be able to release each Chapter to each group when you are ready for them to have access..

Each chapter of the three stories (Rakesh, Estrella, and Felix) is accompanied by a Resource Library for students. When you are ready, you will publish the Resource Library list so the students can see it and access the Resources.
To publish the Resource Library List for each Chapter:
• Drag all the tiles from your Evidence tab (left side of screen, under Curriculum) to your Workspace (right-hand side of screen)
Note: you can multi-select tiles by holding down the shift key when clicking them

• Edit the list, if you wish
  • Click the blue Publish button (rectangle with up arrow) at the upper left of the Workspace
  • Note: everything in your Workspace will be published to the students' Resource Library tab when you click the button. Make sure to delete any tiles that are not part of the Resource List

Tell the students that we are trying something a bit different. Instead of just giving them evidence in a packet like we did for short term stress, we are giving them a story, and different groups have different stories. The stories follow a main character as they try to figure out a health issue that is making them concerned. The characters encounter evidence along the way and use it to figure out the issue.
They should work as a team and assign the cast. The narrator has a lot to read. Other roles have much less.
They should answer the questions and fill in the table in their Workspace.
